Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing a Learner-centered Environment for Algebra-based Physics (LEAP) Curriculum for Diverse Student Populations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers at Tennessee Technological University are expanding and improving the Learner-centered Environment for Algebra-based Physics (LEAP) effort, which has shown success in improving student understanding of important ideas in conceptual physics. The work will include an investigation into students' problem solving ability, and the production of a workbook, interactive electronic learning aids called "Viewlets" and new units on topics including modern physics. These materials are suitable for medium enrollment classes with a diverse student population, and serve to help scaffold students' math and scientific reasoning skills, especially those students who are relatively under-prepared. The research into students' problem solving ability contributes to the understanding of how the reasoning skills involved are developed, and guides the development of a problem solving rubric to measure students' progress toward expert-like skills and a survey to compare students' beliefs with what they actually do when problem solving.

One unusual aspect of this proposal is the focus on collaborative/cooperative group learning in the algebra-based setting---a setting that typically serves more women and other students from underrepresented groups than the calculus-based sequences usually do. For secondary education majors, these courses are seen as especially important, likely to be a rare instance of learning content in a guided-inquiry setting. In addition, the focus on improving students' scientific reasoning abilities helps all students to become more scientifically literate citizens. The materials are suitable for low-cost implementation at many small regional universities and colleges with similar audiences, and the investigators are presenting workshops for other faculty on their use in multiple settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Enhancing the Learner-centered Environment for Algebra-based Physics (LEAP) curriculum for Diverse Student Populations project proposed to enhance the LEAP curriculum through the development of a workbook and two sets of online resources to further help scaffold students' math and scientific reasoning skills in addition to new curriculum units to broaden its scope. To evaluate the effectiveness of the S.E.N.S.E. problem solving strategy in developing students' problem solving skillls, we ulitized an existing problem-solving rubric developed by Jennifer Dockter to measure students' progress toward 'expert-like' skills. The results of this study showed that, when compared to traditionally taught students, LEAP students achieved significantly better scores indicating more 'expert-like' problem solving skills.

LEAP has been developed as a two-semester course sequence for a diverse student population of non-science majors who are relatively under-prepared in terms of their math and scientific reasoning skills. The LEAP curriculum consists of carefully sequenced sets of activities that students work through in small groups. These activities are intended to help students develop a deep understanding of fundamental physics ideas through guided micro-computer-based laboratory and simulation-based experiments and questioning with extensive small-group and whole-class discussion. The current structure of the LEAP course is three 2-hour meetings per week with lecture and laboratory fully integrated into a studio-style learning environment with an enrollment of up to 40 students per course section.

Our evaluations of the first semester course have shown that, when compared to traditionally taught students, LEAP students achieve significantly better gains in conceptual learning as measured by the Force Concept Inventory and improved attitudes toward science as measured by the Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey.

The curriculum materials developed as part of this project have been based on research on science learning and have been built on a proven pedagogical structure with the goal of helping students develop the critical thinking skills and understanding of science needed to become scientifically literate citizens. The curriculum makes extensive use of technology to support student learning including the PhET Interactive Simulations produced by the University of Colorado at Boulder. The research into students' problem solving ability contributes to the understanding of how these reasoning skills are developed.

The enhanced LEAP curriculum benefits all students, but especially females and under-represented groups, since the use of collaborative/cooperative learning has been shown to particularly benefit these groups. Secondary education majors benefit by being exposed to learning the content in a guided-inquiry setting. The enhanced curriculum has impacted around 1305 students over the 4 years of its development. In addition to its impact on students, we have locally trained 6 of our current and former faculty to use the LEAP curriculum. We have presented three half-day workshops at the American Association of Physics Teachers summer meetings. There have been three graduate students who have worked on various aspects of this project. One PhD disseration has been written examining the Force Concept Inventory data generated by this project.
